elements.title: Management’s Discussion and Analysis of R&D Pipeline and Clinical Trials

data.value: We are a biopharmaceutical company dedicated to developing therapeutic monoclonal and bispecific antibodies addressing diseases with unmet treatment needs, focusing on inflammatory diseases and oncology.

Barzolvolimab (also referred to as CDX-0159) is a monoclonal antibody targeting the KIT receptor, currently studied in multiple mast cell driven diseases such as chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU), chronic inducible urticaria (CIndU), cold urticaria, and symptomatic dermographism.
The company is also advancing a next-generation bispecific antibody platform to support pipeline growth with additional candidates for inflammatory diseases and oncology.
According to the provided table, Phase 1 trials are expected to take 1-2 years, while Phase 2 and Phase 3 trials are anticipated to last between 1-5 years each.
The duration and cost of clinical trials are subject to significant uncertainty, influenced by factors such as trial protocol variations and patient enrollment numbers.

elements.title: Research and Development Expenses by Program

data.value: The document details the process of testing drug candidates through preclinical studies and multiple clinical trials, highlighting the uncertainties in development timelines and outcomes. It emphasizes a diversified pipeline approach to manage risks and outlines potential collaborative agreements which may influence project timelines and capital requirements.
The table shows significant growth in total R&D expenses from $42.5M in 2020 to $82.3M in 2022, with notable increases in the Barzolvolimab/Anti-KIT Program and varying trends across other programs.

elements.title: Clinical Development Programs – Barzolvolimab (CDX-0159)

data.value: Barzolvolimab (CDX-0159)
Humanized monoclonal antibody that binds receptor tyrosine kinase KIT to inhibit mast cell activity by blocking SCF binding and KIT dimerization.
Inhibits KIT activity, leading to decreased mast cell growth, differentiation, survival, chemotaxis and degranulation.
Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single ascending dose study in healthy subjects with 0.3, 1.0, 3.0, and 9.0 mg/kg doses.
Multi-center Phase 1b study in CSU patients enrolled in October 2020 evaluating multiple ascending doses as add-on to antihistamines.
Phase 2 studies in CSU and CIndU ongoing; additional studies in prurigo nodularis and planned Phase 2 in eosinophilic esophagitis in H1/ H2 antihistamine refractory patients.
Intravenous in Phase 1 studies; subcutaneous formulation developed for Phase 2 studies.

Mast cell-driven diseases including chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU), chronic inducible urticaria (CIndU), and potentially dermatologic, respiratory, allergic, gastrointestinal, and ophthalmic conditions.

elements.title: Clinical Trial Overview for Barzolvolimab in Urticaria

data.value: In June 2022, the first patient was dosed in a Phase 2 study for Chronic Spontaneous Urticaria (CSU) despite antihistamine therapy.
Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel group study evaluating multiple dose regimens.
Approximately 75 sites across 9 countries.
Approximately 168 patients randomized in a 1:1:1:1 ratio for different dosing arms.

Barzolvolimab at 75 mg every 4 weeks, 150 mg every 4 weeks, 300 mg every 8 weeks, or placebo during a 16‑week placebo‐controlled phase, followed by a 36‑week active treatment phase and a 24‑week follow‐up.
Primary endpoint: Mean change in Urticaria Activity Score over 7 days (UAS7) at week 12; Secondary endpoints include safety, ISS7, HSS7, and AAS7.
Enrollment expected to complete by end of Q3 2023 with topline data reporting late this year or in Q1 2024.

data.key: Phase 1b Study in Chronic Inducible Urticaria (CIndU)
data.value: Initiated in December 2020 in Germany for patients refractory to antihistamines with a single dose (3 mg/kg) in ColdU or symptomatic dermographism; additional cohorts added in 2021 for cholinergic urticaria and a lower-dose cohort in ColdU.

For ColdU and SD cohorts, rapid and durable responses observed with 95% complete response rate and improvements in Urticaria Control Test scores as early as week 4; results published in November 2022.

elements.title: Barzolvolimab Development Activities and Bispecific Platform

data.value: Manufacturing activities to support the clinical program for the barzolvolimab subcutaneous formulation have been completed. In September 2021, dosing was initiated in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase 1 study evaluating safety and pharmacokinetics.
Phase 2 multi-dose studies in urticaria are designed to evaluate doses of 75 mg and 150 mg administered every 4 weeks and 300 mg every 8 weeks, supporting a 0.5 to 2 ml injection volume.
In 2022, the current barzolvolimab manufacturing process was transferred to a contract manufacturing organization to support late-stage trials and prepare for potential commercialization.

Interim data from a six-month chronic toxicology study in non-human primates (reported in February 2022) showed a profound impact on spermatogenesis due to KIT inhibition, with full recovery observed in all male animals during a recovery period that lasted approximately one year, as reported in December 2022.

Development of the next generation bispecific antibody platform is underway with candidates such as CDX-585 and CDX-527 for inflammatory diseases and oncology. CDX-585 combines PD-1 blockade with anti-ILT4 blockade, and CDX-527 couples PD-L1 blockade with CD27 co-stimulation. Both candidates have progressed through preclinical development with IND-enabling studies and are expected to enter clinical trials in 2023.

elements.title: Clinical Trials Program Update & Critical Accounting Policies

data.value: Enrollment for the ovarian cancer expansion cohort did not meet internal timelines; enrollment was closed and the study program discontinued

CDX-1140, a fully human agonist monoclonal antibody targeting CD40, was evaluated in a Phase 1 study in patients with recurrent, locally advanced or metastatic solid tumors and B cell lymphomas. A maximum tolerated dose of 1.5 mg/kg was established with evidence of clinical activity both as a monotherapy and in combination with pembrolizumab. However, despite clinical benefit, broader questions about optimal clinical settings and regimens have led to a decision not to progress further with company-sponsored studies, with future exploration through third-party sponsored studies.
Due to pipeline priorities and resource requirements, further company-sponsored studies have been halted as of August 2022.

The document also discusses significant accounting policies, including contingent consideration from a prior acquisition, revenue recognition, and other estimates that require significant judgment in financial reporting.

elements.title: Table of Contents – Bispecific Platform and Pipeline Overview

data.value: Next generation bispecific antibody platform aimed at expanding the pipeline with additional candidates for inflammatory diseases and oncology. Targets are selected based on new science and compatibility with existing antibody programs.

Combines proprietary PD-1 blockade and anti-ILT4 blockade to inhibit immunosuppressive signals in T cells and myeloid cells. Preclinical studies showed potent inhibition of PD-1 signaling, enhanced inflammatory responses in immune cells, and in vivo efficacy in a melanoma humanized mouse model. Completed GMP manufacturing and IND-enabling studies; expected to enter clinical trials in 2023 for solid tumors.

Uses anti-PD-L1 and CD27 antibodies to couple CD27 co-stimulation with PD-L1/PD-1 blockade, aimed at priming and activating anti-tumor T cell responses. Phase 1 dose-escalation study was initiated but later discontinued after internal review and failure to meet enrollment timelines in the expansion cohort for ovarian cancer.

A fully human CD40 agonist monoclonal antibody targeting a key immune activator on dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells. Phase 1 study conducted in patients with advanced solid tumors and B cell lymphomas, showing some clinical activity. However, due to unresolved questions regarding optimal use and resource prioritization, company-sponsored studies were halted.
The company is open to co-development and commercialization partnerships to support its research and development programs.

elements.title: Table of Contents – Clinical Study Outcomes for Barzolvolimab

data.value: Patients in both treatment groups reported disease impact on QoL; 80% achieved minimal/none (DLQI score 0-1) after dosing.
A single dose of barzolvolimab led to marked decreases in tryptase levels and reduced skin mast cells, correlating with improvements in provocation testing and clinical activity.

Common events included hair color changes (76%), infusion reactions (43%), taste changes (38%), nasopharyngitis (24%), malaise (24%), and headache (19%). Most adverse events were mild and resolved over time.
Data from December 2022 at GA²LEN Global Urticaria Forum showed that while most patients experienced return of symptoms between weeks 12 and 36, some maintained control up to week 36.
In the 1.5 mg/kg cohort, 100% of evaluable patients achieved complete response by provocation testing, with rapid onset (6 of 9 within 1 week) and a median duration of response of over 51 days.

Serum tryptase levels returned to pretreatment levels during follow-up while skin mast cells recovered more slowly; tissue KIT signaling was rapidly inhibited and reactivated around 18 weeks post-dose.

elements.title: Capitalization, Amortization, and Lease Accounting Policies

data.value: Expenditures for property, plant, and equipment are capitalized based on their nature and stage of construction. Costs incurred in project planning, design, construction, and installation are capitalized until the asset is substantially complete and ready for use.
Routine maintenance and repairs are expensed, while significant improvements that extend the asset's useful life are capitalized.

Operating leases for offices, manufacturing, and laboratory spaces are recognized on the balance sheet as right-of-use assets and liabilities, based on the present value of future lease payments. Adjustments are made for prepaid/accrued amounts, initial direct costs, and incentives.

Contingent considerations from business combinations (e.g. acquisition of Kolltan) are recorded at fair value and revalued quarterly. Adjustments depend on factors such as clinical events, regulatory approvals, and discount rates.

IPR&D assets acquired in business combinations are recorded at fair value and capitalized until the underlying project is completed or impaired, after which they are amortized or written down as necessary.

elements.title: Revenue Recognition and Intangible Assets

data.value: Revenues are recognized when performance obligations in contracts are satisfied. The Company uses a cost-to-cost measure (percentage-of-completion) to recognize revenue based on costs incurred relative to total estimated costs. Agreements include nonrefundable signing and licensing fees, research and development funding, milestone payments, and royalties.

Revenue from manufacturing and R&D arrangements is recognized on an output basis. Time-and-material contracts recognize revenue as labor hours and direct expenses are incurred, while fixed-price contracts recognize revenue as work progresses.

Long-lived assets are evaluated for impairment using undiscounted future cash flows. IPR&D assets acquired in business combinations are recorded at fair value, capitalized until project completion or impairment, at which point they are amortized or written down.

elements.title: Financial Disclosure – Cash, Securities, and Risk Management

data.value: The Company considers all highly liquid investments purchased with a maturity date of 90 days or less at the date of purchase to be cash equivalents. These primarily consist of money market funds and debt securities.

Excess cash is invested in marketable securities including municipal bond securities, U.S. government agency securities, and highly rated corporate bonds. These are classified as current assets and stated at fair value with unrealized gains and losses included in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) until realized.

data.key: Concentration of Credit Risk and Significant Customers and Suppliers
data.value: Discussion on financial instruments exposed to credit risk, primarily cash, cash equivalents, marketable securities, and accounts receivable. The Company invests in secure debt instruments and relies on major customers, with revenue from Rockefeller University comprising 75% of total revenue in 2022, and similar concentration disclosures for prior years.

Assets and liabilities are measured at fair value using a three-level hierarchy under U.S. GAAP. Level 1 inputs include quoted prices in active markets; Level 2 inputs use quoted prices for similar assets; and Level 3 involves unobservable inputs based on management's assumptions.

Property and equipment are stated at cost and depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Specific depreciation periods include five years for laboratory and office equipment, three years for computer equipment, and seven to ten years for manufacturing equipment. Leasehold improvements are also noted.

elements.title: Revenue Recognition and Impairment Policies

data.value: Each IPR&D asset is assessed for impairment at least annually or when impairment indicators are present. Long-lived assets, including intangible assets, are evaluated using undiscounted future cash flows to determine recoverability.
If future cash flows are not sufficient to recover the carrying amounts, assets are written down to their estimated fair values.

Revenues are recognized when performance obligations are satisfied. The process includes identifying the contract, determining performance obligations, estimating the transaction price, allocating the price to each obligation, and recognizing revenue as obligations are fulfilled.

Revenue is derived from product development agreements with collaborators (including nonrefundable fees, milestone payments, royalties) as well as manufacturing and R&D arrangements. Recognition methods vary depending on the contract type (cost-to-cost measure for product development, output basis for time-and-material or fixed-price contracts).
Estimations such as cost at completion are complex and subject to many variables including expected clinical trial costs, requiring significant judgment and periodic revisions.

elements.title: Financial Statement Disclosures – Contract Assets, R&D, Patent Costs, Stock-Based Compensation, Foreign Currency Translation, and Income Taxes

data.value: Describes the classification of receivables versus contract assets; contract liabilities are recognized as deferred revenue on the balance sheet when payment is received in advance of performance.

Expenses incurred for research and development include clinical trial costs, manufacturing clinical materials, toxicology, preclinical studies, personnel costs, depreciation, license fees, and funding for external contracted research (CRO and CMO services); costs are expensed as incurred with adjustments for timing differences.
Patent costs are expensed to general and administrative expense as incurred, with certain reimbursed costs recorded as revenues under product development and licensing agreements.

Stock-based awards to employees, consultants, and non-employee directors are expensed based on estimated fair values and recognized using the straight-line method over the vesting period, with adjustments for forfeitures.

Net unrealized gains and losses from foreign currency translation are included in accumulated other comprehensive income; a net unrealized gain of $2.6 million was recorded as of December 31, 2022 and 2021.

The Company applies the asset and liability method for income taxes, recognizes deferred tax assets and liabilities, reviews deferred tax assets quarterly for recoverability, and records uncertain tax positions with interest and penalties where applicable.

elements.title: Risks from Partnership Termination and Competitive Landscape

data.value: Partnership agreements may terminate without benefit if the underlying products are not fully developed. Failure to meet obligations could lead to termination, delay commercialization, and incur additional time and financial costs.

Research collaboration and license agreements (e.g., with Yale University requiring a one-time $3.0 million payment and royalty payments) expose the company to risks in meeting milestones, partner performance, and potential early termination.

The biotechnology and pharmaceutical industry is highly competitive, with numerous companies developing alternative or competing products, which could impact the successful commercialization of drug candidates.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Intellectual Property and Patent Challenges

data.value: There is no assurance that patent applications owned or licensed will result in granted patents or that granted patents will provide effective protection.
Third parties may secure patents that block the use or development of important technologies, impacting commercialization and further development.
Necessary licenses from third parties may be unattainable or only available under costly terms, potentially delaying or preventing product commercialization.

The business faces a heightened risk of intellectual property litigation, with potential challenges to patent validity and enforceability that may lead to substantial legal costs and operational disruptions.

elements.title: Proprietary Rights, Government Regulation and FDA Approval Process

data.value: The document discusses reliance on unpatented technology, trade secrets, and confidential information, along with the use of confidentiality agreements with employees, consultants, and advisors to protect inventions and sensitive information. However, it notes that such agreements may not always provide meaningful protection against unauthorized use or disclosure.

The content emphasizes significant regulation by governmental bodies including the U.S. FDA and comparable international authorities, affecting manufacturing, testing, safety, labeling, documentation, advertising, and sale of products.

Describes the FDA regulatory framework including the need for preclinical studies, IND application before clinical trials, IRB approvals, adherence to good clinical practices (GCP), and the submission of NDA or BLA. It also highlights potential sanctions for non-compliance, such as application refusal, product recalls, fines, and other legal ramifications.
Failure to achieve regulatory approval or proper compliance could impair the company's ability to commercialize drug candidates, affecting future revenues.

elements.title: Регуляторные испытания и утверждение продуктов

data.value: Проведение проверки производственных мощностей на соответствие требованиям cGMP для обеспечения качества и чистоты препарата.
Ожидание утверждения NDA или BLA, рассматриваемых в качестве биологических продуктов, с учетом возможных задержек и изменений в регламентирующих политиках.
Описание этапов клинических испытаний (Фазы 1, 2, 3) с упором на испытания безопасности, эффективности и оптимальной дозировки.
Возможные задержки, неопределенности в интерпретации данных и неожиданные изменения в политике могут привести к задержке или даже отказу в утверждении продукта, что ограничит рынок.
Любые задержки в клинических испытаниях или в процессе регуляторного утверждения могут негативно сказаться на коммерциализации продукта.

elements.title: FDA Regulatory Review and Approval Process

data.value: The document outlines the FDA's evaluation process for NDA and BLA submissions, including facility inspections, clinical site reviews, and compliance with cGMP and GCP requirements.

It distinguishes between an approval letter, which permits commercial marketing with specific indications, and a complete response letter, which details deficiencies requiring further information or testing.
The text highlights risks such as delays, potential rejections, and added costs resulting from the lengthy and uncertain regulatory review process.
Explains the fast track program that expedites the review of drugs intended for serious conditions, including benefits like rolling review and more frequent FDA interactions.
Describes the priority review designation which shortens the review time frame to six to eight months once a complete application is accepted.

elements.title: Regulatory Framework and Risk Factors Overview

data.value: Drug and biologic manufacturers must register with the FDA and comply with cGMP standards. They are subject to periodic unannounced inspections and must obtain prior FDA approval for manufacturing changes.

FDA regulations require investigation and correction of deviations from cGMP, with potential consequences including product recalls, fines, warning letters, post-market clinical trials, and even criminal prosecution.
Non-compliance or emerging issues with manufacturing processes or adverse events can lead to revisions in approved labeling and other regulatory restrictions under risk mitigation programs.
The act establishes an abbreviated approval pathway for biosimilars, including criteria for biosimilarity, exclusivity periods, and procedures for handling patent litigation.
Passed in December 2016, this act is aimed at modernizing healthcare and spurring innovation with increased federal funding for FDA innovation projects and NIH research.

elements.title: Regulatory Risks and Companion Diagnostic Approval Process

data.value: The Cures Act authorizes funding for the 'Cancer Moonshot' initiative, aiming to stimulate drug development via a public-private partnership of 20 to 30 pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies.

Drug candidates may rely on companion diagnostics that require separate FDA clearance through a costly, lengthy, and uncertain PMA process, supported by extensive technical, preclinical, clinical, and manufacturing data.
The PMA application process includes FDA pre-approval inspections of manufacturing facilities and may result in approval, approvable with conditions, or denial, impacting time to market.

Non-compliance with FDA regulations and other federal/state laws can result in various enforcement actions such as fines, injunctions, recalls, or operational shutdowns, adversely affecting business operations.

data.key: Fraud, Data Privacy and Transparency Laws
data.value: The company is subject to federal and state anti-kickback statutes, false claims laws, data privacy, and transparency regulations, which could lead to significant penalties if violated.

elements.title: Regulatory and Compliance Risks

data.value: Outlines the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act prohibiting payment or inducements to foreign officials to obtain or retain business, including interactions with healthcare professionals potentially meeting the definition of a foreign official.

Describes the need to comply with a variety of regulatory requirements in foreign countries for marketing therapeutic or diagnostic products, including safety, efficacy, clinical trials, marketing authorization, and distribution.
Highlights that obtaining regulatory approval in foreign countries can involve extra testing, extended administrative reviews, and that approval in one country does not guarantee approval in another.

Explains that under the EU system, most marketing authorization applications will be submitted via a centralized procedure, which is mandatory for biotechnology-based medicines, cancer treatments, or orphan drugs.
Notes that orphan drug designation in the EU provides economic and marketing benefits, including a 10-year market exclusivity period for the approved indication.
Discusses the uncertainty related to third-party payor coverage and reimbursement rates, which affects sales and could result in higher out-of-pocket costs for patients.
Mentions that evolving legislation, revised FDA regulations, and policy changes could significantly impact product testing, approval processes, manufacturing, and marketing.
Refers to the impact of initiatives like the Inflation Reduction Act and ongoing efforts by governments to contain healthcare costs, affecting drug pricing and reimbursement dynamics.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Drug Pricing, Reimbursement, and Cost-Effectiveness

data.value: The document emphasizes that third-party payors assess the medical necessity and cost-effectiveness of products. If drugs are not deemed cost-effective compared to alternatives, coverage may be denied or reimbursed at lower levels.

data.key: Risk of Limited Coverage and Reimbursement
data.value: There is a risk that, due to unfavorable cost-effectiveness assessments, drugs might not be covered or could face restrictions (such as formulary placement limitations), which would significantly impact projected sales volumes.
Negotiations with hospitals, health systems, and independent delivery networks may be protracted and compromised by concerns over incremental medical benefits and cost-effectiveness.

Pricing and reimbursement schemes vary notably by country (e.g., EU vs. U.S.), including controls like fixed prices, rebates, and utilization restrictions, as well as legislative pressures that may further constrain pricing and coverage.

data.key: Impact of Downward Pressure on Healthcare Costs
data.value: The document highlights a general downward pressure on healthcare costs, which adds to the risk of achieving favorable reimbursement and pricing arrangements for new drugs.

elements.title: Table of Contents for FDA Regulatory Pathways

data.value: Drugs or biologics may receive priority review if they provide a significant improvement compared to marketed products in treatment, diagnosis or prevention of disease. This includes products regulated by FDA’s Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research (CBER).

Under accelerated approval regulations, a drug or biologic for a serious or life-threatening illness may be approved based on a surrogate endpoint likely to predict clinical benefit, with strict post-marketing compliance including Phase 4 trials.

This designation expedites development and review for drugs intended to treat serious conditions where preliminary clinical evidence indicates substantial improvement over existing therapies on clinically significant endpoints.

For drugs intended to treat rare diseases (affecting fewer than 200,000 individuals in the US), orphan designation provides benefits such as a seven-year exclusive marketing period, tax credits, and waiver of application fees, but does not shorten the regulatory review process.

Under the Pediatric Research Equity Act, applications must contain adequate data to assess safety and effectiveness in all relevant pediatric subpopulations, though deferrals or waivers may be granted in certain cases.

After FDA approval, products are subject to extensive post-marketing regulation including recordkeeping, periodic reporting, and additional testing (e.g., Phase 4 trials) to confirm clinical benefits.
